thread.title: Milwaukee Ballet's 'Dracula' a magnetic, mesmerizing production
thread.title_full: Milwaukee Ballet's 'Dracula' a magnetic, mesmerizing production

title: Milwaukee Ballet's 'Dracula' a magnetic, mesmerizing production
text:
Milwaukee Ballet's 'Dracula' a magnetic, mesmerizing production Nathaniel Davauer Davit Hovhannisyan portrays the title character in the Milwaukee Ballet’s “Dracula.” Oct. 23, 2015 1:13 p.m. (0) Comments 
Boy, oh boy, is Dracula back. 
The Milwaukee Ballet's production of Michael Pink's "Dracula" left Thursday evening's Uihlein Hall crowd standing, cheering and whistling. 
Pink's "Dracula combines the fascinating horror of Bram Stoker's story with expressive, dramatic choreography, a few well-placed, beautifully executed theatrical effects, a colorful score by Philip Feeney, and Lez Bortherston's towering, intriguingly dimensional sets and character-defining costumes. 
Relying on a combination of the ubiquity of Stoker's creation, our human fascination with the idea of immortality, Pink's spot-on theatrical sensibilities, and a title character who dances back and forth between steamy sexuality and cold, deadly power, this "Dracula" is worthy of nightmares. 
The production comes across the footlights with a beguiling combination of characteristics from the world of silent film, demanding one's attention to every detail, and the deeply chilling, in-the-moment presence of this particular character in a live production. 
Davit Hovhannisyan was magnetic and powerfully sensual in the title role on Thursday. Gliding steps propelled him across the stage he silently dominated. 
Moving and leaping with leonine strength and ease, he extended that feline character to the way he played with his human prey. When the moment arrived for him to take the blood of one such prey, Lucy, he did so with a seductive kiss to the neck as opposed to a violent bite. 
And that face. That impassive, imperturbable, unreadable and completely mesmerizing face, a character mask he maintained even through curtain calls, making one want to duck behind another patron whenever his gaze turned to the audience. 
Patrick Howell created an everyman character with Harker, through which the audience enters Dracula's world. He danced with power and passion, including a, breathtakingly dangerous pas de deux with the vampire. 
Luz San Miguel danced a heartbreaking transformation from light-footed, girlish innocence to dark, heartless mania. Susan Gartell created a true-of-heart, gracefully serene Mina. 
Denis Malinkine was a sympathetic Van Helsing, with Marc Petrocci dancing a brief pas de deux while wearing a straitjacket in the crazed role of Renfield. 
Alexandre Ferreira created a strong-willed Quincy, matched well by Timothy O'Donnell's Arthur. 
A large supporting cast gave superbly danced, character-filled performances in individual and corps roles. 
Music director Andrews Sill and the Milwaukee Ballet Orchestra gave a spirited, cohesive rendering of Feeney's captivatingly cinematic score, despite occasional awkward amplification. IF YOU GO 
"Dracula" continues through Sunday at the Marcus Center's Uihlein Hall, 929 N. Water St. Visit www.milwaukeeballet.org/ or call (414) 273-7206. © 2015 , Journal Sentinel Inc. All rights reserved.
